question: The powerhouse of the cell is called as
description: Mitochondria are known as the powerhouse of the cell because they produce energy in the form of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) through cellular respiration.

question: The largest bone in the body is
description: The femur (thigh bone) is the largest and strongest bone in the human body. It supports body weight and helps in walking, running, and jumping.

question: The total number of bones in vertebral column is
description: The vertebral column (spine) is made up of 33 bones in total.  They are divided as: Cervical vertebrae ‚Äì 7; Thoracic vertebrae ‚Äì 12; Lumbar vertebrae ‚Äì 5; Sacral vertebrae ‚Äì 5 (fused in adults); Coccygeal vertebrae ‚Äì 4 (fused in adults). So, total = 33 bones (but in adults, sacral and coccygeal fuse, making it 26 distinct bones).

question: Which one of these is the hip bone?
description: The ilium is the broad, upper part of the hip bone. The complete hip bone (coxal bone) is actually made of three fused bones: Ilium, Ischium, Pubis. Together, these form the pelvic (hip) bone.

question: Structure which attaches muscle to a bone is called
description: Tendon ‚Äì connects muscle to bone; Ligament ‚Äì connects bone to bone; Joint ‚Äì a place where two bones meet; Fascia ‚Äì a sheet of connective tissue that covers and supports muscles and organs

question: What is also called a voice box?
description: Pharynx ‚Äì This is the throat region behind the nose and mouth. It helps in both breathing and swallowing. It is not the voice box, but rather a passage for air and food. Larynx ‚Äì The voice box, located below the pharynx. It contains the vocal cords, which produce sound when air passes through them. Tonsils ‚Äì Small lymphoid tissues at the back of the throat. They are part of the immune system, helping fight infections. Trachea ‚Äì Also called the windpipe, it is the tube that carries air from the larynx to the lungs.

question: What is the function of artery?
options: To transport oxygen rich blood from heart to body
To transport oxygen poor blood from body
description: Arteries usually carry oxygenated blood away from the heart (except pulmonary artery which carries deoxygenated blood).

question: What is the function of the Pulmonary Artery?
options: To transport oxygen poor blood from the heart to the lungs
To transport oxygen rich blood from lungs to the heart
To act as a parent artery which helps in supplying oxygen rich blood to the other arteries and then to the body
description: Pulmonary artery is unique because it carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs for oxygenation.

question: What is a coronary circuit?
options: A channel which provides blood to the heart
A channel which provides blood between heart and lungs
A channel which provides blood for the corona patient
description: The coronary circulation supplies oxygen-rich blood to the myocardium (heart muscle) itself.

question: Which part of the brain is also known as the ‚Äúcenter of respiration‚Äù?
description: Cerebrum ‚Äì Controls higher functions like thinking, memory, emotions, voluntary actions. Hypothalamus ‚Äì Regulates temperature, hunger, thirst, circadian rhythm, and hormones. Medulla Oblongata ‚Äì Controls respiration, heartbeat, blood pressure, reflexes ‚Üí Respiration center. Midbrain ‚Äì Controls eye movements, auditory and visual reflexes.

question: The oxygen-rich blood gets pumped into the body from the heart through
description: The aorta is the largest artery in the body. It carries oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle of the heart and distributes it to the entire body through its branches. Superior Vena Cava ‚Äì brings deoxygenated blood from the upper body to the heart. Capillaries ‚Äì tiny blood vessels where exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste occurs between blood and tissues. Arteriole Capillaries ‚Äì small branches of arteries leading into capillaries, but they don‚Äôt pump blood directly from the heart.

question: What is the pH level of blood?
description: The normal pH level of human blood is about 7.35 ‚Äì 7.45. This makes blood slightly alkaline (not neutral). If pH drops below 7.35 ‚Üí called acidosis. If pH rises above 7.45 ‚Üí called alkalosis. Optimal value is usually taken as 7.4.

question: Which system triggers the Fight/Flight response?
description: The sympathetic nervous system (SNS) is responsible for the fight-or-flight response ‚Äî it prepares the body to respond to stress or danger by: Increasing heart rate ‚ù§Ô∏è Dilating pupils üëÄ Releasing adrenaline ‚ö° Diverting blood flow to muscles üí™. Parasympathetic Nervous System ‚Äì does the opposite, "rest and digest". Autonomic Nervous System ‚Äì includes both sympathetic & parasympathetic systems (involuntary functions). Central Nervous System (CNS) ‚Äì brain & spinal cord; processes information.

question: The action of swallowing food is known as
description: Ingestion ‚Äì taking in food (putting it in the mouth). Propulsion ‚Äì moving food along the digestive tract ‚Üí includes swallowing (deglutition) and peristalsis. Eating ‚Äì general act of consuming food (not a scientific term). Absorption ‚Äì nutrients passing from the intestine into blood/lymph.

question: Which organ is not part of Digestive System?
description: Pancreas ‚Äì accessory digestive organ (secretes enzymes + insulin). Liver ‚Äì accessory digestive organ (produces bile). Large Intestine ‚Äì main digestive organ (absorbs water, forms feces). Kidney ‚Äì Belongs to the excretory/urinary system, filtering blood and producing urine.

question: An example of ductless glands is
description: Ductless glands are endocrine glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream (without ducts). Sebaceous gland ‚Üí exocrine (has ducts, secretes sebum). Mammary gland ‚Üí exocrine (secretes milk via ducts). Parathyroid gland ‚Üí endocrine (ductless, secretes parathyroid hormone into blood).

question: What is the major role of calcium in the body?
options: To provide the electrical energy for the nervous and muscular system
To help in thyroid gland‚Äôs health
description: Around 99% of calcium is stored in bones and teeth (so option b seems tempting). However, the major physiological role of calcium is in nerve impulse transmission, muscle contraction, and blood clotting. Bones act as a reservoir, but the body maintains calcium in blood precisely for nervous and muscular functions.

question: The prime hormones released by Adrenal Glands are
description: The adrenal glands (suprarenal glands) have two main parts: Adrenal medulla ‚Üí releases Epinephrine (Adrenaline) and Norepinephrine (Noradrenaline) ‚Üí involved in fight-or-flight response. Adrenal cortex ‚Üí releases Cortisol (a glucocorticoid), along with Aldosterone and Androgens.

question: Which organ has exocrine and endocrine both functionalities?
description: Pancreas has both exocrine and endocrine functions: Exocrine part ‚Üí secretes digestive enzymes (amylase, lipase, proteases) into the duodenum through the pancreatic duct. Endocrine part ‚Üí islets of Langerhans release hormones: Insulin (Œ≤-cells), Glucagon (Œ±-cells), Somatostatin (Œ¥-cells), Pancreatic polypeptide (PP cells).

question: Islets of Langerhans is
description: Islets of Langerhans are clusters of hormone-producing cells in the pancreas. They secrete directly into the blood (ductless, so endocrine): Œ±-cells ‚Üí Glucagon, Œ≤-cells ‚Üí Insulin, Œ¥-cells ‚Üí Somatostatin, PP cells ‚Üí Pancreatic polypeptide. The exocrine part of the pancreas consists of acinar cells, which produce digestive enzymes.

question: The light signal is converted into electrical impulses by
description: In the retina, special photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) convert light signals into electrical impulses through a process called phototransduction. These impulses are then transmitted to the brain via the optic nerve. Pupil only regulates the amount of light entering the eye (doesn‚Äôt convert signals).

question: The coloured portion of the eye is
description: The iris is the colored part of the eye (blue, brown, green, etc.). It controls the size of the pupil (amount of light entering the eye). Lens ‚Üí transparent structure for focusing light. Pupil ‚Üí black circular opening in the center of iris. Cornea ‚Üí transparent outer covering at the front of the eye.

question: Which cells are responsible for vision in low light?
description: Rods ‚Üí specialized photoreceptor cells in the retina responsible for vision in dim/low light (night vision). They are highly sensitive to light but do not detect color. Cones ‚Üí work in bright light, responsible for color vision and sharp details. Cornea & Lens ‚Üí help focus light but do not detect it.

question: The olfactory cortex is responsible for
description: The olfactory cortex, located in the temporal lobe (including piriform cortex & amygdala region), processes information from the olfactory bulb and is responsible for the perception of odors. Touch ‚Üí somatosensory cortex (parietal lobe). Vision ‚Üí visual cortex (occipital lobe). Taste ‚Üí gustatory cortex (insula & frontal lobe).

question: The rough texture of the tongue is because of
description: The rough texture of the tongue is due to small projections called papillae on its surface. Some papillae (fungiform, circumvallate, foliate) contain taste buds. Filiform papillae give the tongue its roughness and help in manipulating food, but do not have taste buds. Mucosa ‚Üí smooth lining, not responsible for roughness. Lymph nodes (tonsils) ‚Üí involved in immunity, not tongue texture.

question: The term Ossicles collectively refers to
options: Mucous Gland, Serous Gland, and Lymph nodes
Superior Semicircular Canal, Posterior Semicircular Canal, and Lateral Semicircular Canal
description: The ossicles are the three tiny bones in the middle ear: Malleus (hammer), Incus (anvil), Stapes (stirrup) ‚Üí the smallest bone in the human body. They transmit and amplify sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane (eardrum) to the inner ear (cochlea).

question: The system which forms the outermost layer of the body is called
description: The integumentary system is the outermost protective layer of the body. It includes: Skin (epidermis, dermis, hypodermis), Hair, Nails, Sweat glands & sebaceous glands. Its main functions are protection, temperature regulation, sensation, excretion, and vitamin D synthesis. Merkel cells ‚Üí touch receptors in skin, not a system. Cochlea ‚Üí part of inner ear, for hearing. External meatus ‚Üí ear canal, not a body system.

question: Skin is the site for Vitamin D synthesis.
description: The skin plays a key role in Vitamin D synthesis: When exposed to UV-B rays from sunlight, the skin converts 7-dehydrocholesterol into Vitamin D‚ÇÉ (cholecalciferol). This is later activated in the liver and kidneys into calcitriol, the biologically active form of Vitamin D.

question: Which is the largest gland in the body?
description: The liver is the largest gland in the human body. Weight: about 1.2 ‚Äì 1.5 kg in adults. Functions: Secretes bile (exocrine function), Metabolism of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, Detoxification, Storage of glycogen, vitamins, and minerals. Synthesis of plasma proteins (albumin, clotting factors). Skin is the largest organ, but not a gland.

question: The sound waves are converted into electrical impulses by
description: In the inner ear, the cochlea contains the Organ of Corti (with hair cells). Sound waves ‚Üí cause vibrations in the cochlear fluid ‚Üí bend the hair cells ‚Üí generate electrical impulses. These impulses are then transmitted to the brain via the auditory (vestibulocochlear) nerve. Eardrum (tympanic membrane) ‚Üí converts sound waves into mechanical vibrations. Stapes & Incus (ossicles) ‚Üí amplify and transmit vibrations, but do not produce electrical signals.

question: Night Blindness happens due to deficiency of which vitamin?
description: Vitamin A deficiency ‚Üí leads to night blindness (nyctalopia) because it is required to form rhodopsin, the visual pigment in the rod cells of the retina (responsible for vision in dim light). Vitamin D ‚Üí bone health (rickets, osteomalacia) Vitamin C ‚Üí collagen synthesis (scurvy) Folic Acid ‚Üí RBC formation (megaloblastic anemia).

question: What should be the pH level of the drinking water?
description: According to WHO and BIS (Bureau of Indian Standards), the acceptable pH range of drinking water is 6.5 to 8.5. Below 6.5 ‚Üí water becomes acidic, corrosive, and may leach metals. Above 8.5 ‚Üí water becomes alkaline, bitter in taste, and may cause scaling.

question: The process of maintaining a stable state within the body is referred as
description: omeostasis = the process by which the body maintains a stable internal environment (like temperature, pH, blood glucose, water balance) despite changes in the external environment. Photosynthesis ‚Üí process in plants to make food. Negative feedback loop ‚Üí mechanism used within homeostasis (e.g., insulin‚Äìglucose regulation), but not the overall process.

question: Which are the processes that are maintained through Homeostasis?
options: The water level in the body
description: Homeostasis helps regulate and maintain stable conditions inside the body, including: Water balance (osmoregulation) ‚Üí controlled by kidneys, ADH hormone. Body temperature (thermoregulation) ‚Üí maintained around 37¬∞C via sweating, shivering, vasodilation/constriction. Production of sound is not a homeostatic process; it‚Äôs a function of the vocal cords.

question: Segmentation occurs in
description: Segmentation is a type of muscular movement in the intestines where circular muscles contract in alternating patterns. Function ‚Üí mixes food with digestive juices and increases absorption by bringing chyme in contact with intestinal walls. Occurs mainly in the small intestine and also in the large intestine. Esophagus ‚Üí shows peristalsis (not segmentation). Mouth ‚Üí chewing, mastication. Stomach ‚Üí churning and peristaltic mixing.

question: The curled part of the small intestine is called
description: The small intestine has 3 parts: Duodenum ‚Äì first part, C-shaped (around pancreas). Jejunum ‚Äì second part, coiled in the upper left abdomen. Ileum ‚Äì third and most curled/twisted part, in the lower abdomen, ending at the ileocecal valve.

question: The basic functional unit of the kidney is called
description: The nephron is the basic structural and functional unit of the kidney. Each kidney has about 1‚Äì1.5 million nephrons. Main parts: Glomerulus + Bowman‚Äôs capsule ‚Üí filtration; Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) ‚Üí reabsorption; Loop of Henle ‚Üí concentration of urine; Distal convoluted tubule (DCT) & Collecting duct ‚Üí final urine formation. Neuron = functional unit of the nervous system.

question: Peptide hormones are
description: Peptide hormones (like insulin, glucagon, oxytocin, ADH): Are made of amino acids ‚Üí hydrophilic (water-soluble). Because they cannot pass through lipid membranes ‚Üí they are lipophobic. Hence, they bind to cell surface receptors (not inside the cell) and act via second messengers (like cAMP).

question: The hormone responsible to prevent blood glucose levels from dropping too low is
description: Glucagon (from Œ±-cells of pancreas) prevents blood glucose from dropping too low by: Stimulating glycogenolysis (glycogen ‚Üí glucose in liver); Stimulating gluconeogenesis (new glucose formation); Increasing blood sugar during fasting or exercise. Insulin ‚Üí lowers blood glucose (opposite effect). Glycogen ‚Üí stored form of glucose, not a hormone. Trypsin ‚Üí digestive enzyme (breaks down proteins), not related to glucose

question: The main sites where Glycogen is stored are
description: Main storage sites of Glycogen in the human body are: Liver ‚Üí stores glycogen to maintain blood glucose levels (for the whole body); Skeletal muscles ‚Üí store glycogen for local energy use during exercise. Adipose tissue mainly stores fat (triglycerides), not glycogen. Pancreas, Small intestine, Bones ‚Üí do not store glycogen significantly.

question: Which of these fluids are related to the eye?
description: The eye contains two main fluids: Aqueous Humor (Fluid) ‚Üí present in the anterior and posterior chambers (between cornea, lens, and iris). Maintains intraocular pressure and nourishes cornea & lens. Vitreous Humor (Fluid) ‚Üí present in the vitreous chamber (behind the lens). Maintains shape of the eye and holds the retina in place. Synovial fluid ‚Üí found in joints, not in the eye.

question: Which of these is responsible for central vision?
description: The macula is a small, specialized area in the retina responsible for central, sharp, detailed vision (like reading, driving, recognizing faces). Its center, called the fovea centralis, contains the highest concentration of cones ‚Üí best visual acuity and color vision. Cornea ‚Üí helps focus light, but not central vision. Optic nerve ‚Üí transmits signals to the brain, but doesn‚Äôt produce vision.

question: Farsightedness is
description: Farsightedness (Hyperopia) ‚Üí A condition where: Near objects appear blurry, but distant objects can be seen clearly. Happens when the eyeball is too short or the cornea is too flat, so light focuses behind the retina. Corrected by convex (converging) lenses. Myopia ‚Üí nearsightedness (opposite of hyperopia). AMD (Age-related Macular Degeneration) ‚Üí affects central vision, but not the same as farsightedness.

question: The smallest bone in the body is found in the
description: The smallest bone in the human body is the Stapes, located in the middle ear. Part of the ossicles (Malleus, Incus, Stapes). The stapes transmits sound vibrations from the middle ear to the inner ear (cochlea). Eye ‚Üí no bones, only eyeball surrounded by orbital bones. Tongue ‚Üí made of muscles, no bones. Nose ‚Üí nasal bones exist, but not the smallest.

question: The smallest bone in the body is
description: The Stapes (in the middle ear) is the smallest bone in the human body. Size: about 3 mm long. It transmits sound vibrations from the incus to the inner ear (oval window of cochlea). Femur ‚Üí largest bone in the body (thigh bone). Septum ‚Üí cartilage + bone in the nose, not the smallest. Incus ‚Üí small middle ear bone, but slightly larger than stapes.

question: The suicide bags of the body is
description: Lysosomes are called the ‚Äúsuicide bags of the cell‚Äù because: They contain powerful digestive enzymes (hydrolytic enzymes). If a cell is damaged or old, lysosomes can burst and release enzymes, leading to self-digestion (autolysis). Ribosomes ‚Üí protein synthesis (protein factory). Erythrocytes (RBCs) ‚Üí carry oxygen, no nucleus/organelles. Merkel cells ‚Üí skin cells for touch sensation.

question: The topmost layer of the skin is
description: The epidermis is the outermost (topmost) layer of the skin. It provides a protective barrier against pathogens, UV rays, and water loss. Made of stratified squamous epithelium. Contains keratinocytes, melanocytes, and Langerhans cells. Dermis ‚Üí middle layer, contains blood vessels, nerves, hair follicles, sweat glands. Hypodermis (subcutaneous tissue) ‚Üí deepest layer, mostly fat (insulation + cushioning).

question: The sum of all the body‚Äôs chemical reactions
description: Metabolism = the sum of all chemical reactions in the body, including: Catabolism ‚Üí breaking down molecules to release energy (e.g., glucose ‚Üí ATP). Anabolism ‚Üí building larger molecules from smaller ones (e.g., protein synthesis). Digestion ‚Üí breaking down food into absorbable molecules (part of metabolism, but not the whole). Absorption ‚Üí uptake of nutrients into the bloodstream. Respiration ‚Üí cellular process to release energy from glucose.

question: The smallest unit of the brain is
description: The neuron is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system, including the brain. Neurons transmit electrical and chemical signals throughout the body. Main parts: cell body (soma), dendrites, axon. Cell ‚Üí general unit of life, but the specialized unit for brain function is the neuron. Nephron ‚Üí functional unit of the kidney.

question: The deepest layer of the skin is
description: The hypodermis (also called subcutaneous tissue) is the deepest layer of the skin. Made mostly of fat and connective tissue. Functions: Insulation to maintain body temperature, Cushioning and protection against mechanical injury, Anchors skin to underlying muscles and bones. Epidermis ‚Üí topmost layer. Dermis ‚Üí middle layer containing blood vessels, nerves, hair follicles, sweat glands.
